title: Introduction to R: the basics
section: Coding is a journey, and this is likely where we all began.
text:
Coding is a journey, and this is likely where we all began.




Excel is widely used for reporting results as it‚Äôs user-friendly and easy to learn.
Prone to manual errors.
Not ideal for large datasets or complex analyses.
Lacks tools for reproducible workflows.

title: Introduction to R: the basics
section: Coding is a journey, and this is likely where we all went.
text:
Coding is a journey, and this is likely where we all went.




Stata is widely used in economics.
Easier to learn than most programming languages.
Less flexible for custom programming.
Expensive!

title: Introduction to R: the basics
section: Coding is a journey, and this is likely where we all want to end up.
text:
Coding is a journey, and this is likely where we all want to end up.




R is free and open source.
It allows us to work on multiple datasets simultaneously (no more keep, preserve, restore hackery).
R is highly flexible and powerful for data analysis.

title: Introduction to R: the basics
text:
Time to start your RStudio!

If you haven‚Äôt downloaded it yet, then follow these steps
Step 1: Download R

Go to the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN):
https://cloud.r-project.org







Tip


R is updated regularly (1 major version/year, 2-3 minor releases). It‚Äôs a good idea to keep R up-to-date, but note that upgrading to a major version will require reinstalling your packages.



Step 2: Download RStudio

RStudio is the Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for R programming.
Download it here:
http://www.rstudio.com/download

title: Introduction to R: the basics
text:
Time to start your RStudio!

Prevents .RData clutter:
Disabling automatic loading and saving of .RData ensures your workspace starts fresh, preventing old or unwanted data from cluttering your environment.
Saves workspace history:
Enables you to track the commands you‚Äôve run, even without saving .RData, making it easier to retrace your steps in the console.

title: Introduction to R: the basics
section: Let‚Äôs start with a good practice!

title: Introduction to R: the basics
section: Are we all familiar with the concept of folder paths?
text:
Are we all familiar with the concept of folder paths?


A path is the address that tells a software where to find a file or folder on your computer.
Just like you need directions to get to a friend‚Äôs house, R needs a path to find your files.



Two Types of Paths:

Absolute Path: /Users/yourname/Desktop/r_training
Relative Path: r_training/scripts

title: Introduction to R: the basics
text:
RStudio makes our lifes easier
R doesn‚Äôt automatically know where your files and folders are located. By using a project, you create a shortcut that tells R exactly where to find everything, making it easier to manage and run your analysis without manually setting file paths.

title: Introduction to R: the basics
text:
Exercise 1 (üïü 5 mins):

Create a folder called r_training on your desktop.
Open RStudio.
Create a Project:

Go to File > New Project.
Make sure to place it in the correct directory by browsing to the r_training folder on your desktop.

Create a Script:

Click the blank page icon in the top-left corner to open a new script.
Save the script by clicking the üíæ icon in the toolbar.
